text.quote: Stone remnants of a 6th century BCE–town, featuring tombs, arches & a well-preserved Roman theater.
trip: Very beautiful roman era town. Theatre (very well preserved), temples (good example of african roman construction), streets (remarkable craftmanship still apparemt), houses, cisterns in a stunning decor of olive trees, fields and hills. Almost no one when I visited in

Dougga, Roman ruins in Tunisia. I was impressed with Ezied when he guided me around Carthage and decided to engage him once again on the tour of Dougga. We departed at 9:00 am and the road was in excellent condition, and the Tunisian countryside, with the vineyards, lush

This is an absolutely incredible site to visit. The extent of the town/city is amazing - and yet there is clearly more to be uncovered. The baths, the temples, the villas, the latrines (yes, even the latrines) are just amazingly well preserved. There is little in the way of

This is one of the highlights of my trip to Tunisia. The Roman city of Dougga is remarkably well preserved. You can tour the Roman Baths, the Temple of Jupiter, the amphitheater, some residences all set on a hill overlooking olive tree filled hillsides. Don't miss this Roman
we had a great tour with our guide Jamel from saharansky, the ruins are unique and spectacular, i recommend the visit of bulla regia as well as it's nearby.

This is an incredible site where you can really imagine how Romans lived. I hired a guide (Mohamed) who was near the site for 30DT/1.5hour, and he was very helpful in adding details about how individuals interacted with the environment. I took a louage very early morning from
Incredible ruined Roman city. Mosaics, statues, a temple, a brothel, a bath house, a theater... all incredible sights.

Someone I work with in Tunis suggested I visit Dougga after I told him I had been to most of the main historical sites. Dougga is one of the main sites so definitely don’t miss it if you have time. I was the only foreigner there and there were only a couple small groups of
This is a large site, with many structures to explore and photograph. I highly recommend it. There are many interesting angles for good photos.

If you are into Roman ruins, this is one of the best sites that I've been to. Very well preserved and not much "restoration." Nice environment of rolling hills and farmland around the site. Definitely a must-see if you are in Tunisia. Hit it early in the morning to avoid the

We took a Louage to Dougga from Tunis and it was super easy. We spent a few hours there and then took a Louage back. Having done Carthage a few days before I can say that Dougga does not disappoint. I am not big into seeing ruins but this was fantastic. There were not a lot of

Stunning Roman ruins. Amazingly well preserved, many temples, gates. Mosaics in situ in beautiful condition, many have been removed to the Bardo Museum. Definitely have a guide to explain the history of the site. If not on a tour, then arrange a guide. Small gift shop. A real

Roman ruins in relatively good condition. You will want to see if in Tunisia. Some of Dougga's best mosiacs are preserved now in the Bardo in Tunis. Be sure to get an on-site guide and be sure to spash water on any mosaics you find onsite before taking a photo (that will

Much larger scale than the Carthage ruins in Tunis. Very well-preserved but without too much attention. Yeah it’s not easy to go unless you hire a car but it definitely worth a shot if you are interested in this kind of ancient Roman stuff.

It was an experience to arrive at Dougga coming from Bulla Regia, but with the help from a very friendly police man who accompanied us a few mile we arrived at destination. Arriving at Dougga at the archeological site is exiting especially when the indications are not that

An amazing Roman city, in a much better condition than any I have ever seen. Supposedly there is only one which is in a better condition but that one is in Libya, so tough luck getting there... We had a 2-hour walking tour with Mouna - licenced guide that we found on the spot

Dougga is located around 100 kilometres from Tunis. There are occasional buses from Bab Saddoun Bus Station to Teboursek but the local way to travel would be to find a louage heading to Teboursek (and then wait for it to fill up) and then enjoy the ride with 7 other people. The

Excellent Roman ruins, well preserved and a lot larger and more spaced out than I expected, I thought it was great, took lots of photos and spent just over an hour at the site. I definitely recommend getting a guide if you'd like to learn more about the site, I felt it was worth
We did not go on the arranged tours to Dougga but went with an individual guide. A beautiful former Roman town with stunning views and set amongst olive groves.
Well excavated and chronicled this is one of Tunis’ best. From the large social public buildings to the red light district, the town has a story to tell.
In Dougga one gets a very good impression of how beautiful these historical cities must have been. The area is lovely and clean, the roads are good. Dougga is worthwhile going.

Well presented and maintained town best developed in roman times. Needs at least 2 - 3 hours to see most of it. Requires a guide. Gives a great flavour of what life must have been like in roman times, main buildings must have been really impressive in their day. Set in
I really recommend this place ,very interesting you can find there a tour guide so he can present the romain civilization in Dougga and the history , lots of ruins .. a must visit.

Dougga is one of the finest Roman ruins I have been to. It is a complete city with an amphitheater, bath, temple, etc.. Everything is in a high state of preservation. It is worth the 2 to 3 hour drive from Tunis. The day I was there, only a handful of other tourists were there.
It was the best place I've ever seen related to Roman culture. I recommend to everyone. Very calm place. There aren't many people so you can relax. In the summer it's very hot so be careful

We arrived here around Noon on a Thursday afternoon, no cars/buses in sight, JACKPOT ! We had the place to ourselves !! First we had lunch at Dar Ejdoud located at the foot of the ruins where you purchase your tickets. We were the only 2 people here had a great lunch at a very

My wife and I were staying in Tunis and rented a car at the airport for the dive to Dougga. It took 2 - 2.5 hours. The first 2/3 of the road is modern four lane highway. The remainder is a two lane road to goes through some beautiful countryside. We had lunch at ta small

You can walk the streets of Dougga and get a real feel for what the city would have been like in its prime 2100 years ago. Take your time and wander through the delightful site, there is so much to see. I spent 3 hours there and only just touched the surface. It is a few

I made the trip detailed by stanberg in 2012. My experience was quite similar six years later. Here are some additions in case they are useful: - In Tunis, take a taxi or the Metro to Bab Saadoun to pick up the louage [shared taxi]. There is a mass of them, almost all with

Dougga offers visitors remarkable insights into 6 historic civilizations. The scale and quality of the ruins help visitors imagine what life was like in a Roman town. Our visit was a stunning, memorable experience. Given the scope, we benefited enormously from a guide. We

This is the best ancient Roman site I have ever visited apart from Pompeii. Built on top of a Phoenician city, which itself was built on top of a Berber settlement, it doesn't have the usual Roman city layout, making it particularly interesting. Only about a quarter of the
This place was absolutely spectacular and well preserved, incredible friendly locals and I absolutely do recommend you to go check it out.

One of the best preserved Roman cities that exist. So worth the drive there and it is extremely useful to have a guide for this place, so that you can learn the detailed workings of the city. Great Temple, amphitheater, roads and feel of the city. Give yourself a few hours to
we loved the full day tour we had with Saharansky on a visit to Dougga and Bulla regia. we thank Ahmed the driver and Jamel the guide for their knowledge and professionalism

This is one of the most spectacular historical sites, that brings together three empires and more than 8000 years of history. Dougga is reachable by public transport. Take a louage (share taxi) from Bab Saadoun louage station to Terboursouk. Trip cost 6.5 TD, and took about 1

The site is a little bit out of the way - it took us about three hours to get there - and even on a beautiful late July day there were only two other groups of tourists, one group of Russians and one group of Chinese, both of which left after about an hour tour so we were left

Desipte the fact that we've visited a number of Roman sites in countries like Turkey, Lebanon, Jordan and Morroco, Dougga still comes top of all. It's a massive area on a plateau overlooking the valley. From the ruins of various buildings and structures, you can imagine the
If you like Roman ruins, this is the place. Staggering, with beautiful country surrounds. I image it would bbq hellishly hot in summer, but in autumn is was near perfect.
Very pretty place and full of history. Really enjoyed the day. Very nice guide and stunning views. Very nice!

Stunning views, amazing place with such a great history. It was a pleasure to walk there and see all these buildings, scluptures, mosaic and other interesting things. The place isn't very well known and you can spend there day almost alone, without crowds making selfies

This time last night I was very wary of going to Dougga as travel information by public transport was scarce. Now I can tell you that it was the easiest trip: I decided to walk from Porte de France (30 mins) to Bab Saadoun Bus and Louage station, immediately found a louage

its the first unesco hertage site that i visit when i but a goal for my self which is to visit all the unesco site around the world if i can . the place is really beautiful but its really sad they leave it to die ... no care .. no service for tourist .. no guide ... i don't know

Absolutely amazing Roman ruins, hard to describe in words or photos how impressive it is. Allow yourself a couple of hours to see the site. There are information boards at different areas giving you the history which are very detailed and well illustrated. We also had lunch in

Dougga is one of the best preserved Roman archaeological sites in North Africa and well worth the 2 or so hours drive out of Tunis. Like most such sites in Tunisia you can pretty much wander where you choose. There's usually an English speaking guide around who for about 10
It's a must see, once in a life time. The place is historical (167-169), imagine that. You can learn in silence about Roman Empire. Very inspiring place.

This Roman Ruin is an incredible heritage site in Tunisia. It's just amazing to see the preservation. It's about roughly 110 km from Tunis. The site is an excellent example of Roman/Byzantium life and governance. A wonderful experience. 5/5

I have seen a lot but this is just unbelievable, the quality and the richness of the site is amazingly well preserved. You are really walking through history in a very cool and relaxed way because it is like walking in an open museum in a park. You can touch and feel the ruins

Quite a lot to see as is, but our guide told they've only uncovered but a few of the 60 hectares still get to uncover I couldn't believe it. The narrow alleyways, the tunnels the slaves used and the roads worn down from carts, almost gives you a feeling of what life was like.

Dougga occupies a fantastic site - on top of a hill overlooking a large fertile plain. Even today, you get a sense of why it was important and the source of its wealth. It is very well preserved and you can see all the normal attributes of a prosperous Roman town - plus some

I really enjoyed this - there's so much here that's preserved so you can really get a feel for the town. You can even see the track marks from the old carts. Mosaics, Roman baths, the town hall - I would definitely revisit this place.

Dougga is about two hours from Tunis. I hired a car to drive me there and to the ruins at Bulla Regia. If you like to explore ruins, this is a very fun sight as there are many different ancient streets and paths winding through the site. Dougga is a large site with a wide

If you visit Tunisia find a way to get to Dougga. The large ruins site is amazing. The best preserved site in North Africa, Dougga ranks up there with any ruins site in Europe that we've visited. Not only are the ruins incredible, but the lush landscape around them make for some

Dougga is a must see if you have a free day in Tunis. We are so glad we made the time to visit (it was a full day trip). To get there, we walked to the northern louage station at Bab Saadoun. A louage driver was yelling "DOUGGA, DOUGGA, DOUGGA" and we hopped in and waited for

It is a couple of hours from Tunis (the capital) but it is worth the drive! very interesting and huge! a lot of building are still intact. If you like historical places this the perfect place to see ancient ruines.

This place combines theaters, temples, baths, houses and Mosaics, it is situated in the north of country and built on top of a hill, it is one of these places where you can walk and touch an enjoy everything. I wish the government pays more attention to this place and start

really nice place to get away from the city. however, the lack of services is not convenient, there is only one restaurant close to the site with below the avg food. if you wanna visit the site it is better to be prepared and have water, refreshments and maybe some snacks too

If you are in Tunisia and have the opportunity to have a car, a hike in the north the country is recommended. This ancient Roman site, restored and very well preserved, is an excellent destination. Children will enjoy a lot. In spring all around are lush green lawns.

Situated on top of a high hill, looking over the plains for approx 50 miles, is this complete roman garrison town - houses, theatre, temples, baths. Mosaics in situ, etc. The best Roman site I have seen!

We visited this site on a relatively hot day but went early so that we were not too exhausted. The site is huge and you could spend hours exploring the whole place but we found an excellent guide who walked us to the major sites of interest in about 90 minutes, finishing at the

We journeyed to Dougga from Sousse in a bus arranged from the hotel. The trip was quite expensive £50 each. But lasted a whole day but included lunch and entrance. The journey is not for those who do not travel well as we were bounced by Tunisian roads the whole way. It did

Dougga is located 2 hours driving from Tunis. I would say such a magnificent archilogical site. I met David at the entrance of amazing theater before i entered to see . The curving of David status ,you can see through his legs under the throb clearly. What a beautiful art!!! The

These are some of the best Roman ruins in North Africa. We spent a couple hours roaming the streets of this once thriving city that originally was Numidian before the Cartaginians arrived followed by the Romans and ultimately the Byzantines. The setting on a hill overlooking a

Superb Roman ruins, well worth a visit. We went as part of an organised tour and our guide was very interesting and informative. It is a long way from the resort areas of Tunisia though, requiring a lot of time on a bus to get there and there is a lot of walking once you're

Spectacular site, with traces of construction from Punic to relatively recent times. Slightly marred by somewhat haphazard partial reconstructions, but more than compensated for by the sheer number of impressive structures, the largest of which is a Roman theatre. A search on

If you only visit one place in Tunisia then visit Dougga. Spectacular ruins with hardly anyone else there. Try to get the female guide as she is very knowledgeable, speaks excellent English and will really bring the place to life. Highly recommended.

I have revisited Dougga after 2 years. The site has much improved and has been well-cleaned and amazingly well-kept. It is even more, now, the best preserved Roman ruins in the whole of North Africa. Well done to the Tunisians. The roads to the site have been very much upgraded

A life-changing experience. Dougga is an absolutely incredible site, large and well-preserved. I cannot rate it highly enough. Give yourself plenty of time (I had 4 hours and could easily have done with more). Transport can be a bit of a hassle. Here's what I did: go to the Bab

These are some of the best kept, more stunning Roman ruins I've ever seen. Best of all, there are hardly any people that visit this place. Unlike somewhere like Ephesus, Turkey where you can expect a small town every day, I saw four Tunisian tourists, and two korean tourists

Awesome is such and overused word its lost its meaning but visit Dougga and you will be in awe. It is truly and definitively awesome. We hired a taxi from our hotel in Sidi Bou Said (10 miles north of Tunis ) and it took just over 2 hours. I agree with just about all the

The only criticism I have about Dougga is the lack of guide. We had read lots of great reviews and have to agree - the site is amazingly well preserved and every corner we turned there were more ruins to explore - not enough to see comfortably in 3 hours at all. We were

If you only visit one place this has to be it. A massive site and some truly wonderful ruins from the phonecian and roman era. Still some still very well preserved buildings and it truely has to be seen to be believed and the access you get is unparalleled - it is worth

Just returned from Dougga this is a must see archeological site as good as anything I have seen in Italy.THe drive from hammamett took about two hours. The drive through the region was beautiful.The amphitheatre was well preserved as are the latrines.November is a great time to

I can proudly say that Dougga is the most fascinating Roman Site, it lies in the middle of the countryside , where you can feel that you are cut from everything around you just you have to close your eyes and feel the glorious past of Dougga.I would advise anyone who loves

We visited here on an organised tour from Hammamet and it is truly amazing. We have visited Roman ruins all over Europe and this is by far the biggest , best preserved and most interesting of them all. It is in the middle of nowhere and we had the site to ourselves with our

This Ruins are great. The Theater is great, the whole site is worth the trip from Tunis. It is a easy 1/2 day trip from Tunis. A guide is a good idea as the site is not marked for exploring on your own, There are rest rooms and a small café on site. Still on working

Wow! This is a terrific site that should be part of any itinerary in Tunisia. It's a good day trip from Tunis, best if combined with Bulla Rigia. It's a fairly large site, yet we were the only people there. As good as almost anything you'll see in Italy. One of the best

Our tour guide insisted that we make the drive from Tunis to Dougga. We are so glad that he did. This site, which is only 30% uncovered, has remnants of a Berber City, which the Romans built on, and which were then developed by other subsequent inhabitants. We had recently

Other than El Jem, Dougga is the must see Punic and Roman ruins \ archaeological site in Tunisia. Not only is the site fascinating, but the region surrounding it is beautiful with its agriculture fields and terrain features. I visited in the middle of October and it was hot.

It is simply beautiful and special. I was there in October 2014 and there were not many tourists around. I had the site almost for myself and spent hours there photographing. The views from the site are also beautiful. It is worth the long road trip from Tunis. Don't miss it. By
The drive from Tunis is long but it is very interesting. If you are not into classics and ancient stone villages stay way. If you are into cool ancient architecture it is really worth a look.

If you ever visit Tunisia do make the effort to take the few hours drive from Tunis to the site. It is very much worth it. A lot more interesting then the few remains of Carthage. Do visit Carthage for the recovered mosaics in the museum.

Stunning setting, with some well preserved buildings. The temple is amazing. We were originally going to get a taxi for the day from Hammamet but decided to be lazy and went on the Thomas Cook trip instead. It was probably for the best as the guide was excellent and very

There was so much more to see here than I had expected. The amphitheatre is really well presserved and the view from the top is breathtaking. The latrines and still in place! The layout of the old houses is really easy to see. There's almost too much to see as I couldn't take

This is one of the most impressive sites in the world! Despite the well-preserved archaeological city and the recognition as Unesco site, the Roman city deserves an improvement of the touristic services: the book shop was closed, there were no audio guides nor archaeological

On a visit we had only two hours and it is not enough. To get to know the city and its sights is needed about four hours. Lots preserved Roman structures that are found nowhere else. Amazing views of the monuments that have survived almost 2000 years. I recommend to visit the

The Roman ruins of Dougga are on the UNESCO World Heritage List for a reason: this is undoubtedly one of the most outstanding examples of Roman architecture worldwide. Although Dougga is somewhat off the beaten path, and perhaps nowadays somewhat a somewhat "adventurous"

We took a louage (6 dinar/person) from station Gare Bab Alouia at 11AM and arrived at 1:30PM. The louage driver phoned ahead to his taxi driver friend who picked us at the side of the road and drove us up the hill to Dougga for 25 dinar (rip off for an 8 min ride. Just let the

I first visited this Roman site in 1973, well before you readers were born! I returned last year with my wife. This time I had hired a car. Still the same! This is a massive Roman site but very few people go there. Such a pity because the location is fantastic and the ruins
This was in the middle of nowhere in the Atlas mountains - a beautiful location. The Roman site is very well preserved. A good tour guide is essential to get the best out of these ruins.

If you like ruins then this is an absolute must - a large site with streets, houses, theatres, baths and temples. The guide was knowledgeable and brought the town to life - a wonderful wonderful afternoon.
Most beautiful ancient city in Tunisia. Great atmosphere and maintained location with lot of nice buildings.
Beautiful place and my most favorite one in Tunisia! Been there twice already and am planning to go again! Especially during april and may! Bring some food for a picnic under the olive trees!!
Prepare your visit: print out or keep available on your phone some guidebook or article about the space: it's a large site and surely deserves to be understood.

Tunisia is a hidden gem, with places like this, as good as anything in Italy, just lying about the country side: very accessibly, few(er) tourists particularly in the low season - we had the place to ourselves.
What a surprise Dougga was to us - the site has an abundance of ruins to explore and photograph. Absolutely worth the trip out from Tunis

Dougga is a must-see for ruins fanatics like me. The ruins are in a excellent state of preservation. In particular, the theatre and the Temple of Jupiter in the forum are quite exquisite. Sitting on the seating in the theatre you can really imagine what it must have been like.

Great Roman site. Loved the in tact ruins and the lack of tourists but that's also bad for the economy. Tourism is off 90% due to instability in the region but it's a great time to go for no crowds. Very safe country, very friendly people.

Amazing Roman ruins, huge site. Because of the unrest in the region, Tunisia being sandwiched between Algeria and Libya, we had the place practically to ourselves. It's a perfect time to visit Tunisia!

This is the most extensive Roman site in the whole of Tunisia and it is as yet only a quarter excavated. It is in a beautiful setting, stretching for miles over rolling hillside. The local guide is excellent and has lots of information to impart. It was one of the highlights of

Fascinating glimpse into history. To the extent that excavation has been done, it has been done very well - better than Carthage. Impressive site that gives great insight into Roman, and Tunisian, culture over a very long period. Well worth the drive to Dougga.

Where to start writing about Dougga? Should I focus on the historical content of a site that has vestiges from for different civilizations? Or just talk about the high ground overlooking a valley with a breathtaking view? Dougga is both a pleasant place to walk around and an

We visited Dougga as part of an arranged trip run by Tunis Travel. It included Thuburgo Majus and Zaghouan Water Temple. This was a one day excursion and with the inescapable travel distance, we travelled from Sousse. Only a limited time could be spent at each attraction but

Dougga was really big and beautiful, But I want to say about the transportation going there and coming back. We started from Tunis to Baesadoon louage station and in there lots of louage drivers came to us to take us to their cars. I can hardly understand them and I said we

To say this site was 'great' would be an understatement. 'Awesome' does not do it justice. You can sit in the amphitheatre and hear voices from the past in the breeze ....... climb into and out of houses......stand on the steps of the Captiol and look 'aristocratic'. This well

Magnificent & stunning , dominated by the Capitole which is in remarkable condition. Set in a beautiful location overlooking fertile fields & olive groves. Wandering around this ancient city : The Theatre , The Square of The Winds , the baths & latrines, the arch Of Septimius
Guide was informative and charming, we did have to barter for the cost of his service. Long drive from our hotel so beware.

This is definitely the hallmark of our trip to Tunisia, a day trip to see Roman ruins. It was during summer and the temperatures could get quite high so carry plenty of drink and preferably wear light clothes. Part of the tour could get a bit steep so probably not suitable for
.t is avery good site where you can step further in the carthagean and roman time.spring and winter are the best seasons to go there.

I lived in Italy for 11 years and traveled in the country extensively.....Dougga is the most remarkable Roman ruin I have ever seen....the theatre is unbelievably well-preserved....only Siracusa comes close. A must-see!

If you go there, get a guide, they Speak English and french. Give them around 20-30 Dinars, (about 20$). It is worth it. Dougga is a Roman City that the visitor will witness details about the living style that was there 1800 years ago. In the Summer they have festivals.

It was Sunday, so me and my two Angolan friends decided to visit the world famous Roman ruins of Dougga. Normally the taxis from the hotels are expensive so we hired a taxi from outside. 99% of people speak French, so we had a hard time in making the taxi driver understand that

The plice are very corrupt and if you get stopped in a car they always ask for money, we were stopped at the end of the Toll road from Beja and we had to pay 50 dinars before they let us go on our journey
This is a large and well excavated site. If you want to walk down a Roman street and see some lovely temples and views, this is the site for you.
A long journey from Tunis but a very special spot ..when we visited it was quiet and peaceful.we visited several other sites which made the trip special..highly recommended
We visited here with our tour group. It is a large site with many excellent photo opportunites. It is generally well preserved and not too busy.
Best preserved site and monuments, helps providing a concrete idea about Roman culture, religious , political centers,their Baths , salves markets and more

Brillant Roman ruines really loved the theatre. Got rushed around by the tour guild and spent most of the day on a coach from Hammermit which we was told we would be on for two hours ended up more like four. Oh and we had to change coaches on the motorway and wasn't told we had

Beautifully-preserved Roman town with amphitheatre, Capitol, baths etc and almost no other tourists. We could explore without pressure and take photos with no one in front of us! Worth taking a guide book to explain what you are looking at. Highly-recommended.
Brilliant remains - particularly the theatre and the forum area. In mid april it was relatively quiet. Not much else on site just a small / shop cafe

Get a taxi to bus station (2 Dinar), then local bus from main bus station to town next to Dougga (6 Dinar), you can walk up to the hill in about 1-2 hours or get a taxi. We caught a mini-bus taxi back, same price and quicker as they use the motorway

Have to visit both Dougga and Bulla Regia if you visit Tunisia. Dougga has many public buildings and Bulla Regia has many underground houses (with in site mosaics) so between the two you get a great idea of everyday Roman life.
This is an incredible sight. A huge site that was almost empty when I visited. The ruins are in great condition, and there is access is brilliant. Well worth a visit.

This is a good Roman site running down the hillside. Very picturesque with grapes and fruit plantings in the countryside.Easy to walk through the ruins and intrigueing to walk down the same access road used by inhabitants two thousand years ago. Good ruins, good access, good

It is a surprisingly big old town in ruins right outside the town of Teboursouk in the middle of nowhere, which is probably why it is in so much better state than anything in Carthage. Take the whole day to visit, as driving from Tunis takes a couple of hours, depending on the

If you are into history even a small interest, this is a must-visit in Tunisia! The ride from Tunis was also very relaxing with the very beautiful and quite Tunisian country side compared to the buzzy capital (we rented a car, 1h30 minutes). When you arrive you get a sudden
incredible well presevered Roman ruins. A must to visit if you are in Tunisia. Not that far from Tunis
A surprisingly large Roman city with lots of interesting buildings especially the temple and the baths. A must see for any trip to Tunisia

If you get offered a trip to Dougga, take it. If you don't, you'll kick your self later. If you have any interest in historical sites, this is a must see. The usual tours will just give you a fair idea of the site, I think the site is over 3 square kilometers and would take a

Without question, the Roman ruins at Dougga are one of the best kept secrets in Tunisia. If you are going to Tunisia, this is the one MUST VISIT - and we toured the whole country! In fact if you like the history, it is worth visiting Tunisia just for this (but take in the

Dougga is worth the hour and a half drive from Tunis to get there. It is an incredible ancient ruin and one of the best parts of my trip t Tunisia. There are very few signs in Dougga though, so make sure to get a tour guide who can explain everything.
It is a Roman City, you can still see how 2000 years ago the Romans use to live in this part of the World, get a guide it is very useful and make your experience richer
Need a car to get there, easily a day can be spent there. There is a small coffee shop with clean facilities. A must!

Amazing site, well worth a visit, but be prepared to eaither go as an organised tour or hire a taxi for the day as it's a way from Tunis! Sturdy walking shoes recommended as the site itself is massive!
Spent the day running through the ruins with my children who loved it and asked to return as soon as possible.
It was really beautiful and well conserved keeping in mind that is located far away from evrything. The trip is a bit loger than expected, but in the way you can get really nice fruits!!!

We took a day trip which included the Water Temple at Zaghouan, Thuburbo Maius, the Commonwealth War Cemetary at Mediez El Bab as well as Dougga. Sometimes it is worth going on a coach trip! The guide was very good and informative. The only problem was that he didn't wait for

history grateness of architecture that last thousands of years even if it needs some rest places restaurant may be or a coffee corner some thing that allows to people to spend the whole day admiring grateness of other culture that lived once on the same place we're living today
Very few tourists at the site. Fortunately there were NO vendors selling souvenirs! You must pay a dinar for a photo vouchers to take photographs.

The ruins are perfectly saved. We were very impressed! It's fantastic. You can easily get the idea about way of life this ancient Roman city. The thermae, public toilets, amphiteatre, good saved houses of rich citizen, bawdy house, temple of Jupiter (it's really great and

Another Roman site, so many around the Med but it deserves its status. As with Sbeitla it is another city but if possible if better preserved. You need some stamina here as there is a lot of climbing but not only are the ruins wonderful but so is the view of the surrounding
far better in many ways to pompeii, but sad that so many artefacts have been taken away since our first visit and it would have been better if the on site shop was open

Dougga or Thugga is an ancient Roman city in northern Tunisia. UNESCO qualified Dougga as a World Heritage Site in 1997, believing that it represents “the best-preserved Roman small town in North Africa”. The site, which lies in the middle of the countryside, built on an

We traveled away from the sea, in a dificult road , a terrible hot day of August, but when we arrived we are amazed by the vue of the city on the top off the hill. Well preserved , very interesting sites , amazing buildings on their feet, and just for you, because the tourist

I've been to a lot o Tunisia's historic sights. All of them have their own pros and cons. But no matter how you look at it - Dougga is to me outstanding! (with El Jem a clear number two). I know of no other place that gives you an overview of what life might have been like. A
Fantastic views. The site gives you a real feel for what a Roman city out in the countryside might have been like at the height of the Empire.

Definitely worth the trip, whichever way you choose to get there. We drove ourselves, having the luxury of a rental car. It's easy to find and easily visited in a day trip from Tunis. There are several choices of route to get there, including a motorway for much of the distance.

I travelled alone and independently in a minivan from Tunis. This was easy and inexpensive, taking under 2 hours for a near 200km journey for 6 dinars. Once off the minivan I met the group of well-heeled “taxi” drivers and their modern vans. The site is about 8km from the

When visiting Tunis, a day trip to Dougga is a must. Despite my reservations about using louage, I decided to go for it and did not regret a single moment of it. To get to Dougga, one can take a louage from Bab Saadoun bus station to Teboursouk, and then take a taxi to Dougga. A

This is not only a well-preserved archaeological site but one of the most beautiful in northern Africa with Timgad in Algeria. Built on a hill, the view over the valley and the hillside is absolutely stunning. Going there at spring time is a real treat.

Fabulous Roman city ruins, in beautiful location. Make sure you take your own guide book and map though. I took 2 hrs and was pretty quick about it; most people I think may want 3 or more. if you use the entrance via New Dougga, its a bit of an uphill walk to get to the

I love Roman ruins and I´ve visited lots of them in many countries. Dougga is not big. Don´t expect a huge Temple or well preserved streets, like in Pompei. But it is unique. You will get the feeling of what it was like living in a small village atop of hill (now in the middle

Well preserved Roman town perched on a hilltop overlooking fertile valleys.A must see for anyone interested in ancient culture. A good guide brings it all to life pointing out the wealth of detail on view at every turn. Amazing place.
Few Roman sites compete Dougga, whether in Tunisia or worldwide. A must for visitors who enjoy diverse cultures.

I am late writing this review of our January 2011 trip, but I wanted to add my vote to this being the most fantastic site around Tunis (along with the Bardo Museum). What made our one day personal tour from Tunis to Dougga especially great was our guide, Mr. Belghith from

Off the beaten track, Dougga (Thugga), a Libyo-Punic town offers one of the best opportunities to imagine life as it was in ancient times. The aqueduct, houses, amphitheater, temples, etc... are wonderful. Most of the artifacts and mosaics are preserved in the Bardo Museum,
For history lovers this is must see place. This show you how the people lived thousands of years ago.

A wonderful place to visit. At the time of my visit, yesterday, there was absolutely no-one there so you had an amazing experience of wandering these ancient ruin in total solitude. This is the best preserved Roman ruin in North Africa. It is surrounded by fertile fields and

We caught a shared taxi Louagge from near the North bus station in Tunis, it cost 6TD each way, took just over an hour to reach Tebersouk where we were dropped off at the Louagge station. A local yellow taxi picked us up within seconds, but saw the pound signs and charged us 10
If there is one Roman site in all of Tunisia to see, this is it. On so many levels, it is beautiful, scenic, amazingly well preserved and a wonderful local guide to boot!

A trip to Dougga allows you to witness the remains of an amazing civilisation away from a major center. The level of preservation and detail that remains is fascinating and the access to all parts of the site is excellent. As it was buried by earth, it is really well preserved

We went in a hired car - not usally recommended for Tunisia but it was fun. Buy a good map before you go. This amazing place is hardly signposted and you have to be determined to keep going to find it but it is well worth it.

I was in Tunisia last week & wanted to go back to Dougga. We went last year but it was raining so I fancied seeing it in the dry. I was told by our Thomson's rep - sorry holiday adviser - that it was closed & she didn't know why. Has anyone any info on this? ~~~~Thanks - Sid -

text.quote: Spacious park offering trails for walking & biking as well as athletic courts & a zoo.
trip: Good place to visit if you like urban parks. It's on a hill and you can get a nice walk. It's got a small zoo too.

Going to the the zoo at Belvedere Park I didn't think I would find a nice zoo but rather borring rows of cages. To my surprise the zoo was better than many in eastern part of the EU. Most antelopes had big green enclosures, the carnivores as well. Just remember its closed on

Disgraceful place. Even some visitors throw rocks and litter at the animals and even stoned a crocodile to death with rocks. Obviously nobody in charge of this kip. Close it down if you can't look after the animals properly.
A beautiful green park, a variety of animals and birds. A beautiful oasis in the city of Tunis for relaxation and walking.

an undignifying. way to treat animals. absolutely scandalous. i visited this place while very young. it was amazing such beautiful memories now it is in a state of desolation. so inhuman to keep animals in those conditions.

This is the unavoidable must place for all Tunisian Children. Even visitors will have the occasion to see the Atlas Lion , the Tunisian jackal, gazelles, wolves... They have now replaced the deceased elephant and added more penguins, hippos, monkeys and birds.. It is a pit that
this park is big one but the animals seem to me are hungry , not in good health but any way its place where you can spend little time with the kids
Historically great park - still worth a visit Issue with cleanliness of place - not always top shape Interesting set of animals - worth it if you're visiting with kids
